Did the Prophet first call to arms even though it would have been justified? Revenge against his enemies? No, rather he calmly appealed for peace.

Mercy, another fundamental Islamic value, is likewise not restricted to Muslims alone. Islam teaches us to be merciful to all of Allah’s creation, as long as that mercy is not at the expense of an innocent person’s rights.

Allah said:

وَمَآ أَرْسَلْنَـٰكَ إِلَّا رَحْمَةًۭ لِّلْعَـٰلَمِينَ

We have sent you only as a mercy for the whole world.

Surat al-Anbiya’ 21:107

Abdullah ibn Amr reported: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said:

الرَّاحِمُونَ يَرْحَمُهُمْ الرَّحْمَنُ ارْحَمُوا مَنْ فِي الْأَرْضِ يَرْحَمْكُمْ مَنْ فِي السَّمَاءِ

The merciful will be shown mercy by the Most Merciful. Be merciful to those on the earth, and the One in the heavens will have mercy upon you.

Source: Sunan al-Tirmidhī 1924, Grade: Sahih

Abu Musa al-Ash’ari reported: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said,

لَنْ تُؤْمِنُوا حَتَّى تَحَابُوا أَفَلا أَدُلُّكُمْ عَلَى مَا تَحَابُونَ عَلَيْهِ

You will never have faith until you love each other. Shall I tell you what will make you love each other?

They said, “Of course, O Messenger of Allah.” The Prophet said:

أَفْشُوا السَّلامَ بَيْنِكُمْ فَوَالَّذِي نَفْسِي بِيَدِهِ لا تَدْخُلُونَ الْجَنَّةَ حَتَّى تَرَاحَمُوا

Spread peace between yourselves. By the One in whose hand is my soul, you will not enter Paradise until you are merciful to others.

They said, “O Messenger of Allah, all of us are merciful.” The Prophet said:

إِنَّهُ لَيْسَ بِرَحْمَةِ أَحَدِكُمْ خَاصَّتَهُ وَلَكِنْ رَحْمَةُ الْعَامَّةِ

Verily, it is not only mercy between yourselves, but rather it is mercy for everyone.

Source: al-Sunan al-Kubrā lil-Nasā’ī 5760, Grade: Sahih

The mercy of Islam extends even to animals and the smallest of Allah’s creatures.

Abu Huraira reported: The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said:

غُفِرَ لِامْرَأَةٍ مُومِسَةٍ مَرَّتْ بِكَلْبٍ عَلَى رَأْسِ رَكِيٍّ يَلْهَثُ قَالَ كَادَ يَقْتُلُهُ الْعَطَشُ فَنَزَعَتْ خُفَّهَا فَأَوْثَقَتْهُ بِخِمَارِهَا فَنَزَعَتْ لَهُ مِنْ الْمَاءِ فَغُفِرَ لَهَا بِذَلِكَ

A prostitute had once been forgiven. She passed by a dog panting near a well. Thirst had nearly killed him, so she took off her sock, tied it to her veil, and drew up some water. Allah forgave her for that.

Source: Ṣaḥīḥ al-Bukhārī 3321, Grade: Muttafaqun Alayhi

Ma’qil ibn Yasar reported: I said, “O Messenger of Allah, I had taken the goat to slaughter it, but I had mercy on it.” The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said:

فَإِنْ رَحِمْتَهَا رَحِمَكَ اللَّهُ

If you had mercy on it, Allah will have mercy on you.

Source: Shu’ab al-Imān lil-Bayhaqī 10557, Grade: Sahih

Al-Sharid ibn Suwayd reported: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said:

مَنْ قَتَلَ عُصْفُورًا عَبَثًا عَجَّ إِلَى اللَّهِ يَوْمَ الْقِيَامَةِ يَقُولُ يَا رَبِّ إِنَّ فُلَانًا قَتَلَنِي عَبَثًا وَلَمْ يَقْتُلْنِي مَنْفَعَةً

Whoever kills so much as a sparrow unjustly, it will plead to Allah on the Day of Resurrection, saying, ‘O Lord, he killed me unjustly, and he did not kill me for any beneficial purpose!’

Source: Ṣaḥīḥ Ibn Ḥibbān 5894, Grade: Jayyid

The scholars of Hadith recognized the relevance of such narrations to the concept of jihad. In response to the question of whether Muslims are allowed to burn idolaters in retaliation, Imam al-Bukhari records a Hadith in which Allah scolds a Prophet because he collectively punished an ant colony.

Abu Huraira reported: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said:

أَنَّ نَمْلَةً قَرَصَتْ نَبِيًّا مِنَ الأَنْبِيَاءِ فَأَمَرَ بِقَرْيَةِ النَّمْلِ فَأُحْرِقَتْ فَأَوْحَى اللَّهُ إِلَيْهِ أَفِي أَنْ قَرَصَتْكَ نَمْلَةٌ أَهْلَكْتَ أُمَّةً مِنَ الأُمَمِ تُسَبِّحُ

An ant bit one of the Prophets, so he ordered that the colony of ants be burned. Allah revealed to him, ‘One ant has bitten you, so you destroy one of the nations that praise Allah?’

Source: Ṣaḥīḥ al-Bukhārī 3019, Grade: Muttafaqun Alayhi

The implication is that if collective punishment is blameworthy against creatures as tiny as ants, it is even more blameworthy against human beings. The Prophet ﷺ did not allow innocent people to be killed for crimes committed by someone else, effectively outlawing the cycle of blood feuds that plagued Arabia at the time.

Ibn Mas’ud reported: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said:

لَا تَرْجِعُوا بَعْدِي كُفَّارًا يَضْرِبُ بَعْضُكُمْ رِقَابَ بَعْضٍ وَلَا يُؤْخَذُ الرَّجُلُ بِجَرِيرَةِ أَبِيهِ وَلَا بِجَرِيرَةِ أَخِيهِ

Do not return to unbelief after me by striking the necks of each other. No man is to be punished for the crimes of his father or his brother.

Source: Sunan al-Nasā’ī 4127, Grade: Sahih

These numerous texts remind us that behind the legal discussion of the jurists, the theory and practice of warfare must conform to the Prophet’s ﷺ mission to be a mercy to the worlds. To this end, Muslims are obligated to accept credible peace offerings from their enemies whenever they are offered.

Allah said:

فَإِنِ ٱعْتَزَلُوكُمْ فَلَمْ يُقَـٰتِلُوكُمْ وَأَلْقَوْا۟ إِلَيْكُمُ ٱلسَّلَمَ فَمَا جَعَلَ ٱللَّهُ لَكُمْ عَلَيْهِمْ سَبِيلًۭا

If they refrain from fighting you and offer you peace, then Allah does not permit you to harm them.

Surat al-Nisa’ 4:90

And Allah said:

وَإِن جَنَحُوا۟ لِلسَّلْمِ فَٱجْنَحْ لَهَا وَتَوَكَّلْ عَلَى ٱللَّهِ إِنَّهُ هُوَ ٱلسَّمِيعُ ٱلْعَلِيمُ

If the enemy is inclined towards peace, make peace with them. And put your trust in Allah. Indeed, He alone is the All-Hearing, All-Knowing.

Surat al-Anfal 8:61

Ali ibn Abi Talib reported: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said:

إِنَّهُ سَيَكُونُ بَعْدِي اخْتِلَافٌ أَوْ أَمْرٌ فَإِنْ اسْتَطَعْتَ أَنْ تَكُونَ السِّلْمَ فَافْعَل

Verily, after me there will be conflicts or affairs, so if you can end them in peace, then do so.

Source: Musnad Aḥmad 695, Grade: Sahih

The classical jurists derived several legal categories that allow peace with unbelievers, even if the Muslims do not have political control over them.

Imam al-Mawardi writes:

اعْلَمْ أَنَّ مَا تُحْقَنُ بِهِ دِمَاءُ الْمُشْرِكِينَ يَنْقَسِمُ أَرْبَعَةَ أَقْسَامٍ هُدْنَةٌ وَعَهْدٌ وَأَمَانٌ وَذِمَّةٌ

Know that the lives of idolaters are spared in four cases: a truce, a covenant, a pledge of security, or a tribute for citizenship.

Source: al-Ḥāwī al-Kabīr 14/296

In accordance with the Quran, the Prophet ﷺ let enemies go if they promised to stop attacking the Muslims, as an act of mercy and a demonstration of Islam’s magnanimity in victory.

Allah said:

وإِنْ أَحَدٌۭ مِّنَ ٱلْمُشْرِكِينَ ٱسْتَجَارَكَ فَأَجِرْهُ حَتَّىٰ يَسْمَعَ كَلَـٰمَ ٱللَّهِ ثُمَّ أَبْلِغْهُ مَأْمَنَهُۥ ذَٰلِكَ بِأَنَّهُمْ قَوْمٌۭ لَّا يَعْلَمُونَ

If anyone from the idolaters asks for your protection, grant it to them so they may hear the Word of Allah, then escort them to a place of safety, for they are a people who have no knowledge.

Surat al-Tawbah 9:6

Ibn Zayd, may Allah have mercy on him, explained:

إِنْ لَمْ يُوَافِقْهُ مَا يَقُصُّ عَلَيْهِ وَيُحَدِّثُهُ فَأَبْلِغْهُ مَأْمَنَهُ وَلَيْسَ هَذَا بِمَنْسُوخٍ

If he does not accept what is narrated and told to him, then escort them to a place of safety. This has not been abrogated.

Source: Tafsīr Ibn Abī Ḥātim 29:6

Allah not only relents against His enemies without forcing their conversion, but He even excuses them for their ignorance, just as the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, prayed when his face was slashed at the battle of Uhud:

اللَّهُمَّ اغْفِرْ لِقَوْمِي فَإِنَّهُمْ لا يَعْلَمُونَ

O Allah, forgive my people for they do not know.

Source: Ṣaḥīḥ Ibn Ḥibbān 973, Grade: Hasan

In one incident, an idolater snuck up to the Prophet ﷺ to kill him, but eventually lost his sword to him. When the Prophet pointed the weapon at him and asked him to become Muslim, the man refused to convert to Islam, but he said:

أُعَاهِدُكَ عَلَى أَنْ لَا أُقَاتِلَكَ وَلَا أَكُونَ مَعَ قَوْمٍ يُقَاتِلُونَكَ

I pledge not to fight you and not to join anyone who fights you.

The Prophet accepted these terms and let him go, so when the man returned to his tribe, he exclaimed:

جِئْتُكُمْ مِنْ عِنْدِ خَيْرِ النَّاسِ

I have just come to you from the best of the people!

Source: Musnad Aḥmad 15190, Grade: Sahih

The Prophet ﷺ did not want to kill the man. He wanted him to embrace Islam. The wisdom in letting him go is that he returned to his tribe, praising him for his generosity, which raised his reputation and embodied the values of Islamic mercy, potentially converting more hearts and minds.

In practice, many jurists limited peace treaties to a ten-year term, as was the international custom at the time. However, others set no limit at all, paving the way for permanent peace treaties, as adopted by most Muslim countries today.

Imam Malik, may Allah be pleased with him, said:

تَجُوزُ مُهَادَنَةُ الْمُشْرِكِينَ السَّنَةَ وَالسَّنَتَيْنِ وَالثَّلَاثَ وَإِلَى غَيْرِ مُدَّةٍ

It is permissible to contract a peace treaty with the idolaters for one, two, or three years, or without any time limit.

Source: Tafsīr al-Qurṭubī 8/41

There is nothing in Islam to prevent lasting peace with non-Muslims as long as the freedom and security of Muslims are guaranteed and innocent people are not being slaughtered.

All avenues of peace and reconciliation must be pursued as much as possible, while any covenant, promise, or truce with the enemy must be strictly upheld. It is absolutely forbidden for Muslims to unilaterally violate peace treaties, plot political assassinations, or make false promises to the enemy. Anyone who does so will be condemned by Allah and all creation on the Day of Judgment.

Ibn Umar reported: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said:

إِذَا جَمَعَ اللَّهُ الأَوَّلِينَ وَالآخِرِينَ يَوْمَ الْقِيَامَةِ يُرْفَعُ لِكُلِّ غَادِرٍ لِوَاءٌ فَقِيلَ هَذِهِ غَدْرَةُ فُلاَنِ بْنِ فُلاَنٍ

When Allah gathers the earlier and later generations on the Day of Resurrection, He will raise a banner for every treacherous liar. It will be announced that this is the betrayal of this person, the son of this person.

Source: Ṣaḥīḥ al-Bukhārī 6178, Grade: Muttafaqun Alayhi

Abu Huraira reported: The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said:

الْإِيمَانُ قَيَّدَ الْفَتْكَ لَا يَفْتِكُ مُؤْمِنٌ

Faith has prohibited assassination. A believer does not assassinate.

Source: Sunan Abī Dāwūd 2769, Grade: Sahih li ghayrihi

Anas ibn Malik reported: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said:

لَا إِيمَانَ لِمَنْ لَا أَمَانَةَ لَهُ وَلَا دِينَ لِمَنْ لَا عَهْدَ لَهُ

There is no faith for one who cannot be trusted. There is no religion for one who cannot uphold a covenant.

Source: Musnad Aḥmad 12383, Grade: Hasan

Some people claim Muslims cannot be trusted because the Prophet ﷺ noted, “War is deception,” and Muslims are allegedly at war with the entire non-Muslim world, but this is false. The Prophet was only expressing the same fundamental truth as Sun Tzu in his famous treatise on warfare, “All warfare is based on deception.”

In Islam, deceiving the enemy is only permitted as a necessary tactic in war, such as misdirecting troop movements, conducting covert reconnaissance, and confusing the enemy.

Ka’b ibn Malik reported: When the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, intended to set out on a military expedition, he would pretend to go somewhere else. The Prophet would say:

الْحَرْبُ خَدْعَةٌ

War is deception.

Source: Sunan Abī Dāwūd 2637, Grade: Sahih

The Prophet ﷺ said this because it is a limited exception to the general rule of truthfulness.

If the Muslims accept a treaty or make a promise to the enemy, they are obligated to be faithful to it. This rule is so strict that it must be upheld even at the cost of disadvantaging Muslim forces. Those who violated the peace were sometimes threatened with capital punishment because sabotaging a legitimate truce is an extreme act of wickedness against everyone involved.

The Caliph Umar ibn al-Khattab, may Allah be pleased with him, wrote to a commander in an army he had dispatched, saying:

إِنَّهُ بَلَغَنِي أَنَّ رِجَالًا مِنْكُمْ يَطْلُبُونَ الْعِلْجَ حَتَّى إِذَا أَسْنَدَ فِي الْجَبَلِ وَامْتَنَعَ قَالَ رَجُلٌ مَطْرَسْ يَقُولُ لَا تَخَفْ فَإِذَا أَدْرَكَهُ قَتَلَهُ وَإِنِّي وَالَّذِي نَفْسِي بِيَدِهِ لَا أَعْلَمُ مَكَانَ وَاحِدٍ فَعَلَ ذَلِكَ إِلَّا ضَرَبْتُ عُنُقَهُ

I have heard that it is the habit of some of your men to chase an unbeliever until he takes refuge in a high place. Then a man tells him in Persian not to be afraid, and when he comes down, they kill him. By the One in whose hand is my soul, if I knew a man had done that once, I would strike his neck.

Source: al-Muwaṭṭa’ Riwāyat Yaḥyā 2/448

And Umar said:

وَاللَّهِ لَوْ أَنَّ أَحَدَكُمْ أَشَارَ بِأُصْبُعِهِ إِلَى السَّمَاءِ إِلَى مُشْرِكٍ فَنَزَلَ إِلَيْهِ عَلَى ذَلِكَ فَقَتَلَهُ لَقَتَلْتُهُ بِهِ

By Allah, if one of you were to give a gesture of safety to an idolater and he came trusting you and you killed him, then I would execute him for it.

Source: Sunan Sa’īd ibn Manṣūr 2597, Grade: Qawi li ghayrihi

In one instance, a peace treaty was signed between the Caliph Mu’waiyyah and the Romans. Mu’waiyyah was marching his army towards their country so that when the covenant came to an end, he would attack them by surprise. A man came riding on a horse, shouting, “Allah is Most Great! Allah is Most Great! Let there be faithfulness and not treachery!” The Caliph sent for him and questioned him, so the man said he heard the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, say:

مَنْ كَانَ بَيْنَهُ وَبَيْنَ قَوْمٍ عَهْدٌ فَلَا يَحُلَّنَّ عَهْدًا وَلَا يَشُدَّنَّهُ حَتَّى يَمْضِيَ أَمَدُهُ أَوْ يَنْبِذَ إِلَيْهِمْ عَلَى سَوَاءٍ

If one has a covenant with people, he must not unilaterally modify it until its term comes to an end, or he brings it to an end in agreement with them.

Source: Sunan al-Tirmidhī 1580, Grade: Sahih

Thus, Mu’waiyah returned with his army. Dispatching the troops before the end of the treaty was technically an unlawful act of war itself, and a surprise attack would inevitably undermine any possibility of reconciliation or peace, so the Caliph recognized his mistake and pulled back his troops. Faithfulness to eternal Islamic values is far more important than any temporary, tactical military advantage.

The moral teachings of Islam were paramount to the Salaf. They feared Allah more than their enemies. They were worried that their own sins were more dangerous than their foes because sins cause the loss of Allah’s assistance in their struggle, as well as punishment in the Hereafter.

The Caliph ‘Umar ibn ‘Abdul ‘Aziz, may Allah have mercy on him, would say:

وَلا تَكُنْ فِي شَيْءٍ مِنْ عَدَاوَةِ عَدُوِّكَ أَشَدَّ احْتِرَاسًا لِنَفْسِكَ وَمَنْ مَعَكَ مِنْ مَعَاصِي اللَّهِ فَإِنَّ الذُّنُوبَ أَخْوَفُ عِنْدِي عَلَى النَّاسِ مِنْ مَكِيدَةِ عَدُوِّهِمْ

There is nothing of the hostility of your enemies that deserves more caution than your own selves and those with you who are sinfully disobedient to Allah. For I fear the sins of the people more than the plots of their enemies.

Source: Ḥilyat al-Awliyā’ 5/302

In every circumstance, either before or during hostilities, Islam has forbidden every type of war crime and transgression for the purpose of minimizing bloodshed, destruction, religious persecution, and suffering as much as possible.

Shaykh Wahbah al-Zuhayli, an internationally recognized expert on Islamic law, summarizes the rules of armed jihad:

شرع القتال في سبيل الله لرد العدوان وحماية الدعوة وحرية الدين الإلهي كان تشريع القتال متصفا بالعدل والحق فهو لا اعتداء فيه على أحد ولا يتجاوز فيه ما تقتضيه الضرورة الحربية وليس الهدف منه التدمير والتخريب ولا الإرهاب المجرد فلا يقتل غير المقاتلين ولا تقتل النساء والصبيان ونحوهم من الرهبان والعجزة والمرضى والشيوخ ولا تقطع الزروع والثمار ولا تذبح الحيوانات إلا لمأكلة كما جاء في الوصايا النبوية ووصايا الخلفاء الراشدين لم يكن القتال لإكراه الناس على اعتناق الإسلام فذلك منفي أصلا في شريعة القرآن

Fighting in the way of Allah was legislated to repel aggression, to protect the call to Islam and freedom for the divine religion. The legislation of fighting is characterized by justice and truth, as there is no aggression against anyone and no excess of what is required by military necessity. Its aim is not destruction, sabotage, or simply terrorism. Non-combatants are not to be killed, nor are women, children, and the like of monks, the infirm, the sick, and the elderly. Crops and fruits are not to be cut down, and animals are not to be slaughtered except for food, as stated in the Prophetic instructions and the instructions of the Rightly-Guided Caliphs. Fighting is not to force people to embrace Islam, as that is fundamentally denied in the law of the Quran.

Source: al-Tafsīr al-Munīr 2/183

To conclude, jihad is a broad concept in Islam that includes both spiritual and military meanings. The spiritual jihad to purify one’s heart is the most important, often classified by scholars as ‘the greater jihad.’ The physical or ‘lesser jihad’ is nevertheless an essential duty upon Muslims to protect their countries, save the oppressed, and remove obstructions that prevent people from accepting Islam of their own free will. The rules of engagement in jihad prohibit the killing of civilians, initiating wars without legal justification, or acting treacherously towards the enemy.

Success comes from Allah, and Allah knows best.
